hypothesis: Temperature gradients point toward heat sources. Gradient-based initialization should provide better starting points for CMA-ES than hottest-sensor approach.

config.note: smart + tri (2 inits, same as W2)

tuning_runs.finding: Smart init: 1.1639 @ 69.6 min - BETTER than gradient init

delta.note: Gradient init is WORSE in both score and time

best_overall.note: Neither config is in budget. Smart init is better than gradient init.

baseline_to_beat.note: Current W2 baseline runs at ~70 min today, suggesting 58.4 min was measured under different conditions

success_criteria.note: Gradient init should improve convergence speed and/or accuracy

conclusion: FAILED - Gradient-based physics-informed initialization does NOT improve over simple hottest-sensor approach
key_findings: Gradient init achieves score 1.1593 vs smart init 1.1639 (-0.0046)
Gradient init takes 71.9 min vs smart init 69.6 min (+2.3 min)
Temperature gradients at sensors don't accurately point to source locations
Heat diffusion from multiple directions and boundary effects corrupt gradient signal
Simple hottest-sensor approach is already a good initialization strategy
